TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Very-fine, smectitic, thermic Typic Natraquerts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Tachi clay - on a slope of less than one percent in a wheat field at 159 feet elevation.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated).  When described on December 11, 1980, the soil was slightly moist below 5 inches and moist below 22 inches.
Ap--0 to 5 inches; very dark gray (5Y 3/1) clay, black (5Y 2/1) moist; strong medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, very sticky and very plastic; many very fine and few fine roots; few very fine tubular and common very fine interstitial pores; slightly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 1.3, SAR 4; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 9 inches thick)
A--5 to 14 inches; dark gray (5Y 4/1) clay, black (5Y 2/1) moist; strong coarse prismatic structure; very hard, firm, very sticky and very plastic; many very fine and few fine roots; common very fine tubular and interstitial pores; slightly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 3.7, SAR 12; moderately alkaline (pH 7.9); abrupt wavy boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
Ak--14 to 22 inches; variegated dark gray (5Y 4/1) and olive gray (5Y 5/2) clay, variegated black (N 2/0) and black (5Y 2/1) moist; few fine prominent reddish yellow (5YR 6/6) mottles, red (2.5YR 4/6) moist; strong very coarse prismatic structure; very hard, firm, very sticky and very plastic; common very fine roots; common very fine interstitial pores; few fine irregularly shaped dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) concretions moist; common intersecting slickensides; strongly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 2.4, SAR 14; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); abrupt wavy boundary.  (7 to 14 inches thick)
C1--22 to 28 inches; variegated dark gray (5Y 4/1) and olive gray (5Y 5/2) clay, variegated black (N 2/0) and very dark gray (5Y 3/1) moist; common fine prominent reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) mottles, strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) and black (N 2/0) moist; weak medium prismatic structure; very hard, firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine and fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; many intersecting slickensides; slightly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 2.2, SAR 12; moderately alkaline (pH 8.1); abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
C2--28 to 35 inches; variegated dark gray (5Y 4/1) and light gray (5Y 7/1) clay, gray (5Y 5/1) moist; many medium prominent strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) mottles, black (N 2/0) and strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist; massive; very hard, friable, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; common intersecting slickensides; slightly effervescent, lime in few fine irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 2.0, SAR 16, strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); clear wavy boundary.  (4 to 8 inches thick)
Ckn1--35 to 47 inches; gray (5Y 5/1) clay, very dark gray (5Y 3/1) moist; common fine prominent reddish yellow (7.5YR 7/6) and few fine prominent light olive gray (5Y 6/1) mottles, reddish brown (5Y 4/4) and gray (5Y 6/1) moist, and common fine distinct black (N 2/0) mottles moist; massive; extremely hard, friable, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine tubular pores; many pressure faces; strongly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped masses; EC 2.8, SAR 26; strongly alkaline (pH 8.6); abrupt wavy boundary.  (10 to 22 inches thick)
Ckn2--47 to 63 inches; dark gray (5Y 4/1) clay, variegated dark gray (5Y 4/1) and very dark gray (5Y 3/1) moist; few fine prominent pink (5YR 7/4) mottles, yellowish red (5YR 4/6) mottles moist; massive; very hard, friable, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine tubular pores; many pressure faces; strongly effervescent, lime disseminated and in common fine irregularly shaped soft masses and in common filaments; EC 3.2, SAR 34; very strongly alkaline (pH 9.3); abrupt smooth boundary.  (10 to 26 inches thick)
Ckn3--63 to 70 inches; variegated gray (5Y 6/1), dark gray (5Y 4/1) and light olive gray (5Y 6/2) clay, variegated dark gray (5Y 4/1) and very dark gray (5Y 3/1) moist; common fine prominent reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6), yellowish red (5YR 4/6) moist, and few fine distinct black (5Y 2/1) mottles moist; massive; very hard, friable, sticky and very plastic; few very fine tubular pores; many pressure faces; violently effervescent, lime disseminated and in common medium irregularly shaped soft masses; EC 4.6, SAR 39, strongly alkaline (pH 8.8).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Fresno County, California, in the Mendota Wildlife Refuge; 120 feet north of a road and 180 feet west of a road; 1,420 feet east and 120 feet north of the southwest corner of sec. 22, T. 14 S., R.  15 E., MDBM.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The soil is saturated in some or all parts at some time of the year.  The mean annual soil temperature is 60 to 70 degrees F.  It is typically saline-sodic in some part of the profile.  Electrical conductivity of the saturation extract is 0.5 to 8.0 mmhos.  When the soil is dry, vertical cracks extend from the surface to a depth of 20 to 40 inches and are 1 to 6 inches wide.   Intersecting slickensides occur below a depth of 5 inches.  Clay content ranges from 60 to 75 percent above 1 meter, but it is 40 to 75 percent below 1 meter.
The Ap horizon is not present in all areas.  The A horizon has dry color of 5Y 4/1, 3/1, 5/2 and moist color of 5Y 2/1, 2/2, 3/1; or N 2/0.  Above 1 meter, if chromas are 1.5 or higher, there are distinct or prominent mottles.  There are mottles in the lower part of the A horizon.  Moist mottles are distinct or prominent and have color of 5YR 4/6, 4/4; 2.5YR 4/6; 5Y 5/3; or 2.5Y 5/4.  In some areas mottles are not present in this horizon.  The A horizon is neutral to moderately alkaline.  Sodium adsorption ratio ranges from 0 to 30 percent.
The C horizon has dry color of 5Y 7/1, 6/1, 6/2, 5/1, 5/2, 4/1; or 10YR 7/2 and moist color of 5Y 6/3, 5/1, 5/2, 5/3, 5/4, 4/1, 4/2, 3/1, 3/2, 2/1; 2.5Y 4/2; 10YR 4/2; or N 2/0.  Moist mottles are distinct to prominent and have color of 7.5YR 5/8, 5/6, 4/4; 5YR 4/6, 4/4, 3/3; 10YR 5/6, 4/6, 4/4; 5Y 6/3, 6/1, 5/4, 5/3, 4/4, 2/1; 2.5Y 6/6, 5/6; or N 2/0.   Above 1 meter, if chromas are 1.5 or higher, there are distinct or prominent mottles.  It is clay or silty clay.  Sodium adsorption ratio ranges from 0 to 70 percent.  Gypsum crystals may be present in the C horizon.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Clear Lake, Hildreth, Maxwell, Subaco, and Willows series in other families.  They are all in a fine particle size class.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Tachi soils are on flood plains and in basins.  Slopes are 0 to 1 percent.  Elevation is 150 to 170 feet.  The soils formed in alluvium from sedimentary and igneous rock.  The climate is arid with dry, hot summers and mild, somewhat moist winters.  The mean annual precipitation is 7 to 8 inches.  Mean January temperature is about 44 degrees F; mean July temperature is about 81 degrees F; mean annual air temperature is 62 to 64 degrees F.  The frost-free season is 245 to 255 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Lillis (T), Nahrub, and Westhaven series.  Lillis soils have a moist color value more than 3.5 and a dry color value more than 5.5 throughout the upper 30 cm in more than half of each pedon.  Nahrub soils are in a fine family without intersecting slickensides.  Westhaven soils are fine silty.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained; ponded runoff; very slow permeability.  The watertable has been lowered to 4 to 6 feet by dam construction and overdraft.  These soils are occasionally flooded.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for wildlife habitat and recreation.  Vegetation consists primarily of Timothy and Watergrass.  They are also used for cotton and wheat production.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Central San Joaquin Valley, California.  The series is not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Fresno County, California, 1985.  Tachi soils are named after an Indian tribe in the area.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Previously mapped as Merced clay in the Soil Survey of the Mendota Area, California, Series 1940, No. 18.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Mollic epipedon - (not necessary for this taxonomic class) - 0 to 14 inches (Ap, A).
Common to many intersecting slickensides and many pressure faces occur in the typical pedon below a depth of 14 inches.
ADDITIONAL DATA:  NSSL #827419, 827420, 827421.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
